children.subject: It's not an enforced prereq because the spring 2020 website (course also taught by Shewchuk) mentioned 'CS 70, EECS 126, or Stat 134 (or another probability course)'. EE 126 and Stat 134 cover more probability that cs 70, but I do have at least the cs 70 level of understanding from stat 88 and ieor 172. I definitely don't have the discrete math background of cs 70 or math 55, though.

There's no discrete math in Shewchuk's 189, at least not at the level that CS 70 goes into. The real application of 70 comes from its probability theory and general preparation for more complicated math topics. I don't know if Stat 88 and IEOR 172 are replacements because I never took those courses.

In terms of self-studying, CS 70 has really great online notes for the class, so if you read those and can do well on the homeworks then you can definitely pick up enough understanding to pass 189.

I would take the prereq's for this class seriously, though. Every class you don't take is another chunk of understanding you won't have. You can totally pass the class and know how to apply the ML methods with just self-study 70 and basic linear algebra background, but you probably won't understand 189 enough to have a strong intuition on how those methods work or what their shortcomings are.
Thanks, that's really helpful! What's your opinion on the linear algebra and multivariable calc reqs? Should I self-study math 110 or is 54 enough? Is self studying or taking 53 necessary?

FWIWI I haven't taken 189 yet, but am currently in 53. Based off what my friends in 189 said, taking math 53 for the sole purpose of 189 isn't too important, because the information from 53 used in 189 is relatively easy to self-study. I can't comment on 54 or 110 because I haven't taken either of those classes

<md>Hey Anon Gear -- I took 189 with Shewchuk last spring. I will say the linear algebra + multivariate portions are incredibly important. You are expected to have decent mastery over concepts like semipositive definite matrices (which I didn't when I went in, and had a _very_ rough time). If you were to take this class without 53, I'd recommend you to read up on partial derivatives and gradients for matrices, as that will come into heavy usage. I don't mean to scare you, just to inform you so you don't get steamrolled like I did! Best of luck!

[Here's a resource the 189 TAs wrote.](https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/tjwju9d9qkgead9in8qus/CS189_-Everything-You-Need-to-Know-about-Gradients.paper?dl=0&rlkey=zirfi7j6ntikr9yxssa4fwegg) I'd recommend looking at it and learning concepts that aren't familiar from there as a good starting point.</md>
Not really the answer you are looking for, but CS70 is very important for a lot of CS upper divs and am not sure if you are allowed to enroll in 189 without it

history.content: I want to take CS 189 next semester with prof Shewchuk. For context, I will be a second semester Junior majoring in data science and using the class for my machine learning elective. I have taken math 54, stat 88 and ieor 172 but that is the entirety of my background in probability and linear algebra. I don't want to take math 53/55/110 or cs 70 or ee 126/127 because I really don't have the time and got into my major very late as it is. I am prepared to study whatever is needed to be prepared for the class over winter break. Is that possible? What should I study to best prepare and where should I source the materials?
history.subject: CS 189 without math 53 and cs 70
